verses.text: Then he brought me back to the entrance of the temple, and I saw water flowing out from under the threshold of the temple toward the east—the temple faced east. The water was coming down from beneath the south side of the temple, south of the altar.
verses.comment: The vision begins at the temple, the central place of worship, with water flowing east—symbolizing blessing and life. The physical temple points toward the universal dwelling of God among His people, which prophetically anticipates the living water Christ would provide (see John 7:38).

verses.text: He brought me out by way of the north gate and led me around outside to the outer gate by the way that faces east; and there the water was trickling out from the south side.
verses.comment: The path of Ezekiel around the temple emphasizes a guided discovery of God’s provision. The symbolic journey suggests the gradual and ordered revelation of spiritual mysteries.

verses.text: As the man went out east with a measuring line in his hand, he measured a thousand cubits and led me through the water; it was ankle-deep.
verses.comment: The progressive measuring underscores the gradual deepening of spiritual life and grace available to all who journey further with God.

verses.text: Again he measured a thousand and led me through the water—it was now knee-deep. Again he measured a thousand and led me through—the water reached my waist.
verses.comment: The increasing depth points to spiritual growth. Engagement with God's life is personal and deepens as one continues forward in faith.

verses.text: Again he measured a thousand, and it was a river I could not cross, because the water had risen; it was deep enough to swim in, a river that no one could cross.
verses.comment: The overwhelming fullness signifies the abundance of God’s grace, and its inexhaustibility. This also recalls the living water Christ gives, which becomes a spring of eternal life.

verses.text: He said to me, 'Son of man, have you seen this?' Then he led me back along the bank of the river.
verses.comment: The angelic guide urges Ezekiel to reflect on the vision. The phrase is commonly used for reflection and understanding of deeper truths.

verses.text: When I returned, I saw a great number of trees on both sides of the river.
verses.comment: The abundant trees echo the imagery of the righteous in Psalm 1 and the tree of life in Revelation 22. These symbolize spiritual fruitfulness and restoration.

verses.text: He said to me, 'This water flows east toward the Arabah and descends into the plain, then enters the sea; when it flows into the sea, the water there becomes fresh.'
verses.comment: The transformation of salty water to fresh symbolizes renewal and redemption—wherever God's life flows, it heals.

verses.text: Wherever the river goes, every living creature that swarms will live, and there will be very many fish. Where this water flows, everything will live.
verses.comment: The river brings abundant life, echoing creation motifs. The universality of the water’s healing foreshadows the worldwide scope of God's restorative work.

verses.text: Fishermen will stand beside it; from Engedi to Eneglaim they will spread their nets. Its fish will be of many kinds, like the fish of the Great Sea, very many.
verses.comment: The multitude of fish and fishermen anticipates the call to be fishers of men (cf. Matthew 4:19) and the bringing in of peoples from all nations.

verses.text: But its swamps and marshes will not become fresh; they are left for salt.
verses.comment: These areas remain unchanged, highlighting that not all will receive the fullness of transformation; a subtle hint of judgement and distinction within the restored order.

verses.text: On both banks of the river, every kind of tree for food will grow. Their leaves will not wither, and their fruit will not fail. They will bear fresh fruit every month, because the water from the sanctuary flows to them. Their fruit will be for food, and their leaves for healing.
verses.comment: This echoes the tree of life imagery in Revelation, suggesting ongoing spiritual nourishment and healing—a perpetually fruitful life connected to God's sanctuary.

verses.text: Thus says the Lord GOD: 'These are the boundaries by which you shall divide the land among the twelve tribes of Israel. Joseph shall have two portions.
verses.comment: Joseph receiving two portions recalls the special blessing given to his sons Ephraim and Manasseh (Genesis 48:5), highlighting God’s faithfulness to ancestral promises.

verses.text: You shall divide it equally, for I swore to give it to your forefathers. This land shall fall to you as an inheritance.
verses.comment: The language of oath and inheritance underscores the unbreakable nature of God's covenant, drawing a parallel with the promise fulfilled in salvation history.

verses.text: This shall be the boundary of the land: On the north side, from the Great Sea by way of Hethlon to the entrance of Zedad;
verses.comment: The detailed description of boundaries is reminiscent of traditional land allotments (Numbers 34:8), pointing to God’s order and care in providing for His people.

verses.text: Hamath, Berothah, Sibraim (which is between the border of Damascus and the border of Hamath), and Hazer-hatticon, which is on the border of Hauran.
verses.comment: The boundaries serve to unite the tribes under a unified inheritance, a sign of reconciled fellowship and order.

verses.text: So the border will run from the sea to Hazar-enan, on the boundary of Damascus, toward the north, in the direction of Hamath. This is the north side.
verses.comment: The precision of these borders highlights the importance of divine order, a theme found in both testaments.

verses.text: On the east side, the boundary will run from between Hauran and Damascus, along the Jordan, between Gilead and the land of Israel, until it reaches the eastern sea. This is the east side.
verses.comment: The focus on landmarks like the Jordan links the vision with the entry to the Promised Land (Joshua 12:1), signifying fulfillment and spiritual inheritance.

verses.text: On the south side, it runs from Tamar as far as the waters of Meribath-kadesh, then along the brook of Egypt to the Great Sea. This is the south side.
verses.comment: Reference to places of covenant and miracle (like Meribath-kadesh) reinforce the theme of God’s action in history and His provision.

verses.text: On the west side, the Great Sea shall be your boundary to a point opposite Lebo-hamath. This is the west side.
verses.comment: The sea as a boundary recalls how the Lord sets limits for His Creation, offering both stability and identity to His people.

verses.text: You shall divide this land among yourselves according to the tribes of Israel.
verses.comment: The inheritance is communal, signifying unity among God’s people and foreshadowing the unity of the holy congregation comprising all believers.

verses.text: And you shall allot it as an inheritance for yourselves, and for the foreigners who reside among you and have children among you. They shall be to you as native-born Israelites; with you they shall be allotted an inheritance among the tribes of Israel.
verses.comment: This inclusive vision reveals God’s plan for those outside Israel to be welcomed into the one household of faith, prefiguring the open call of the Gospel to all nations.

verses.text: In whatever tribe a foreigner resides, there you shall give him his inheritance,' declares the Lord GOD.
verses.comment: The blessing of inheritance for foreigners signals a future unity in God's people, where no distinction remains among those who are part of the covenant assembly. This vision points to a catholicity (universality) of the faith rooted in inclusion and unity, aligning with the vision of one holy apostolic church established throughout salvation history.
